newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: Swiss bank says favouring Mexico for funds.
newsitem.headline: Swiss bank says favouring Mexico for funds.

text.p: Leading Swiss private Bank Union Bancaire Privee said on Monday it was favouring Mexico over Argentina in asset allocation for Latin America.
In its latest survey of weekly trends, it said good news had been plentiful from Mexico since the announcement during the summer of second quarter growth of 7.2 per cent.

The August inflation figures, at 1.33 pct the lowest since the Mexican financial crisis in January 1995, the national budget surplus and lower interest rates "have strengthened our positive view of Mexico's economy," the survey said.
Government policy "will stimulate lasting growth, which will be reflected in corporate earnings," it added.
The bank, which specialises in private and institutional asset management, said that in Argentina short-term visibility had deteriorated.
Though macro-economic fundamentals were perfoming well, "political uncertainties are a source of anxiety," the survey said.
Some populist elements, the bank declared, were using the unemployment and loss of purchasing power hitting ordinary Argentines to hold up the reform process.
The cloudy political perspective had created an unfavourable risk/reward ratio, although parliamentary debates on economic reform in October should provide a clearer picture, it said.
"Meanwhile, we are underweighting Argentina in favour of Mexico," the survey added.
